title: 108_hr4431
content: The Act may be cited as "One Church, One Child Act of 2004". The findings are outlined in Section 2. The Congress finds a shortage of qualified foster and adoptive parents, with a decrease in foster parents despite an increase in children in foster care. There is a significant number of children awaiting adoption, with a growing need for post-adoption support. The rapid increase in adoptions from foster care has created a need for post-adoption services. One Church, One Child is a national organization providing services for at-risk children and adoptive families. One Church, One Child's mission is to provide services for at-risk children and support adoptive, foster, and kinship families. The organization has successfully placed over 140,000 children in adoptive families. Despite its success, limited federal funding has been received. A federally-funded grant program to support recruitment of foster and adoptive parents based on their model is needed. A federally-funded grant program is needed to support the recruitment of foster and adoptive parents based on the successful One Church, One Child model, benefiting abused and neglected children by increasing the pool of qualified parents. SEC. 479B. ONE CHURCH, ONE CHILD GRANTS are added to Part E of title IV of the Social Security Act to support the recruitment of foster and adoptive parents based on the successful model, benefiting abused and neglected children. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities to establish or expand programs that recruit and train foster and adoptive parents through networks of public, private, and faith-based organizations. Eligible entities include State or local governments, public agencies, nonprofit organizations, and private entities. Eligible entities for grants under this section include State or local governments, public agencies, nonprofit organizations, and private entities, including charitable or faith-based organizations. They must submit an application with project descriptions and details on the number of children to be served. The eligible entities for grants must submit an application with project descriptions, details on the number of children to be served, and a description of services for prospective adoptive and foster parents. They should also outline how they will coordinate with State and local entities responsible for recruitment of foster and adoptive parents. The eligible entities for grants must cooperate with State and local entities responsible for recruitment of foster and adoptive parents, as well as with the national clearinghouse. They must also agree to maintain records, submit reports, and cooperate with reviews and audits as required by the Secretary for oversight purposes. The term 'State' in this section refers to each of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The term 'State' includes 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The Secretary is authorized to appropriate up to $20,000,000 annually from 2005 to 2009. Unused grant funds must be returned to the Secretary, who will redistribute them as needed. The Secretary will redistribute any unexpended grant funds among eligible entities in need. Religious organizations are considered equally for grants, as long as they comply with the Establishment Clause. Religious organizations can receive grants for programs as long as they adhere to the Establishment Clause. Governments cannot discriminate against religious organizations based on their religious character. Additionally, religious organizations cannot be required to change their internal governance or remove religious symbols to be eligible for grants or programs funded under this section. Religious organizations receiving grants must not use funds for sectarian worship, instruction, or proselytization. They are subject to the same fiscal regulations as other nongovernmental organizations. Religious organizations receiving grants must adhere to the same fiscal regulations as other nongovernmental organizations, including keeping funds separate and accounting for their use according to accepted accounting principles. SEC. 479C. NATIONAL CLEARINGHOUSE FOR ADOPTION PROMOTION AND FOSTER PARENT RECRUITMENT PROGRAMS; ANNUAL REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to coordinate activities for recruiting foster and adoptive parents and providing support to foster families. Faith-based organizations assist in coordinating recruitment of foster and adoptive parents, providing post-placement support, offering technical assistance and training, and collecting data on program effectiveness. The curr_chunk discusses the collection of data on the effectiveness of programs funded under section 479B, including the number of children placed, foster and adoptive parents recruited, and assisting the Secretary in preparing required reports. The curr_chunk describes the criteria for a nationally recognized, nonprofit adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment organization selected by the Secretary on a competitive basis. This organization must have experience in providing consultation and training to faith-based and community organizations interested in adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment. The Secretary selects a nonprofit organization with national reputation in recruiting and training foster and adoptive parents, particularly through faith-based and community organizations. The organization must have experience in implementing programs based on the One Church, One Child model. Up to $1,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009. Annual reports are required to be submitted to Congress detailing the grant activities. From 2005 to 2009, the Secretary must submit annual reports to Congress on grants made under section 479B. The reports should include the number of entities receiving grants, foster parents and adoptive families recruited, children placed with them, and outcomes of placements. Additional relevant information may also be included for program evaluation.
